story:
The Saga of Lucimia

Welcome to The Saga of Lucimia, a high-fantasy, group-based MMORPG that hearkens back to a time when players worked together to achieve goals that were greater than what they could achieve on their own.  

A time when teamwork, friendship and community meant more than "everyman" games chock-full of single-serving, on-the-rails questlines designed to take you to max level in a matter of days in such a way that you never have to interact with another player to achieve the "end game". 

No mini-maps. No quest hubs. Zero solo content. 3-4 man overland content, 8-man dungeons, and multi-group raids. No flashing icons over the heads of NPCs telling you who to talk to or where to go, no glowing trails leading you from quest objective to quest objective. 

Languages, factions, ruins, cities, dungeons, and more. A massive world to explore, and a classless, skill-based game where you create your own story with your friends and allies. 

Explore emergent gameplay in a world where the players determine the hot spots, the best places to hunt, their favorite dungeons, routes to and from cities, camp spots, and beyond. With zero single-player storylines guiding you or funneling you from Point A to Point B. Sandbox, not themepark. 

Welcome back to the days of group-based gaming. 


The Fellowship of the Ring was not just one character. Jason had his Argonauts. Zeus went up against The Titans alongside The Olympians. History and mythology is full of examples of epic battles waged in the battle of good versus evil…and none of them are fought single-handed.

Modern-day television enraptures this essence as well, with shows like Firefly, Lost, and The Walking Dead all showcasing a team of players facing up against the odds. And we’ve seen it over the years as well; Star Trek, Babylon 5, Battlestar Galactica (both the original and re-imagined), Stargate and beyond.

The greatest adventures are undertaken by groups. The greatest challenges can only be overcome with allies. The greatest rewards come from deeds performed alongside your peers. Dragons aren’t slain by lone heroes; it takes a team of well-oiled champions battling together to bring it down…and then share in the spoils of war together.

If you grew up on Dungeons and Dragons, Ultima Online, EverQuest, and Vanilla World of Warcraft, than you know exactly what we are creating: a group-based game where the only way to move forward is by making strategic progression with allies by your side. 


Our World 

Get back to basics with a challenge-based MMORPG focusing on epic adventure the moment you step outside the safety of the city walls. 

This is more than just a game. Ours is a living, breathing world with a rich, deep texture of history and lore, where danger lurks around every corner and adventure awaits the moment you step out of any door.

Magic is non-existent at this point of the world, which is where Volume I picks up, 500 years after the Archemage Chaldeon took the Book of Knowledge into hiding, deeming mankind unfit to handle the responsibility that came with having access to great power. 

Now, all that is left behind are the architectural masterpieces the Elder Races once created, as well as dungeons, scrolls, relics and books that the Scholar’s Guild protects at all costs in a vain attempt to retain as much mastery over their once-great power as possible. Over time, however, their ability to control the relics, decipher the runes and texts and tap into the once-powerful magic, is fading.

You are born into a world where magic is nothing more than a distant memory. Mankind gets things done with the sweat of their brow and with their own two hands. Master Scholars are able to augment the day-to-day aspects of living with various relics, and adventurers with the relevant understanding of runes, lore and the ancient texts can tap into the hidden power of armor and weapons, but the days of Adepts and magic and spells and Elder races are nothing more than myths and legends shown in ancient paintings and faded scrolls and books and stumbled across in long-forgotten dungeons.

We have planned 40 overland zones, 10 dungeons, and 6 cities to explore within The Saga of Lucimia upon completion. And while there is an underlying main storyline that will take you through the game world as you follow along the events of Volume I in The Story So Far, leading you through forests, mountains, ancient dungeons and beyond to uncover the resting place of the Book of Knowledge and bring magic back to the realm (Volume II), the quest content is 100% optional. 

Remember: sandbox, not themepark.

If you want to skip the major storylines and quests of the game and just go out there and grind dungeons and overland content and raids with your friends, that's your choice. But if you also enjoy epic storylines, there are multiple chains that you can follow along with, and a rich backstory + in-game lore to immerse yourself in. 

The main storyline will lead you through small group content (3-4 players) in the overland zones, into the depths of tombs, dungeons, and ruins where 6-8 players are required, and on to multi-group raids where only the truly dedicated will be able to follow along and achieve epic weapons and armor sets as a result of their investment. 

There are also major storylines related to the overall world and the areas, cities, and outposts. Think the Coldain Ring and Shawl quests from EverQuest. Every questline we are creating is an epic, multi-stage, multi-group campaign meant to span weeks and months. There is no such thing as a single-serving or single-stage quest in the Saga of Lucimia. 

And every single moment is based around challenge.


What Is Challenge?

If you make the decision to leave the safety of town and its guards, it’s not a decision you should be making lightly. You need to prepare for an adventure that will take multiple game sessions to complete. 

Zones will take hours to multiple game sessions to cross, depending on if you stay on the path or head off into unmarked territory. Dungeons will take weeks to months to complete. Ours is not a game to be played in five minute chunks of time. Ours is a world where you invest yourself just as much as in the real world, and meet up with your friends, family, and allies for scheduled game sessions, just like a D&D campaign around the coffee table. 

You need a balanced group of adventurers to handle whatever you might come across in the wild. You need gear. You need supplies. Bandages. Potions. Scrolls. A pack mule and mounts. Wagons. Extra leather, wood, steel, sharpening stones, tools, and rope. Never leave home without a good length of rope.

It’s an excursion, not an afternoon stroll down to the river to pick daffodils for your sweetheart or mum.

Think the Mines of Moria; we want every dungeon and adventure our players encounter to be on par with what The Fellowship encountered while being forced to skip the pass and head into the mines.

That being said, we understand the limitations of Real Life. Sometimes you can't commit to lengthy gaming sessions day in and day out. You've got a job, spouse, kids, other hobbies, and other commitments. That's what mechanics such as our Camps & Caravans system are being designed for.

Beyond that, we're adding other mechanics to up the ante. For example, there won't be mini-maps in this game. You'll be navigating based on your own ability to figure out where you are in the world or a given zone. You'll be able to find maps for cities that you can store in your inventory and open up to help you navigate the streets, but there won't be a glowing dot with a "You Are Here" marker; you'll still need to be able to read the map and figure out where you are in the city.

There will also be NPC-dropped maps that are part of quest chains, as well as those given to you by NPCs as part of quests, but those won't be linked to a mini-map. Instead, it will be based on your ability to read the map in real-time and navigate the world using descriptions and landmarks in conjunction with those maps...if any exist in the first place for whatever it is you are looking for.

And yes, there will be corpse runs; if you die in the wild, your gear will remain on your corpse and it will be up to you (and your friends) to work your way back to where your corpse remains to recover your gear and continue your adventure.


The Game

The Saga of Lucimia MMORPG is a group-based, classless game where there are no levels. Instead, we are using a skill-based character system where you can create whatever type of Player Character you want. 

Your selection of skills defines your playstyle and your class. Upon character creation you have the option to choose which skills will define your character during your time in the unfolding saga, customizing your character based upon your own unique combination of skills.

The content of the world can only be overcome by balanced groups of Player Characters leveraging a wide array of skills throughout the Archetypes. The challenges you face are not merely combat-based. Mechanical and magical traps, locks, doorways, and more abound in our world, and if you lack the skills to detect/unlock/overcome those challenges, your progress will come to a halt. 

Dungeons have entire sections dedicated to mechanical traps and doorways that can only be overcome by player with Thief abilities. Other sections are locked away behind magical doorways and rune traps that only a trained Scholar can bypass or detect. If you walk into a dungeon with purely Adventurer Archetypes, you may very well pass by entire wings without even knowing they exist. Or walk into a cavern in the middle of the mountains and never even detect the dungeon entrance in the first place.

Or pass by that tunnel that rises above you and never know that there is an entire wing above the party, because your characters lack climbing skills or tools, and because no one was paying attention and only looking forward. 


While you can create a character from scratch and choose your own skills to start, there is also a list of pre-designed Archetype builds that most long-term gamers and table-top players will be familiar with, such as Monk, Ranger, Thief, Bard and beyond. These builds have pre-selected skill combinations that best define them based upon lore and the type of character they represent. There are also sub-builds, such as the Archer version of the Warrior, or the Assassin version of the Thief.

In addition, these pre-built Archetypes have special advanced abilities assigned to them. Such as a Ranger build having Advanced Tracking. While a player just starting out can choose Tracking at the beginner level, if they want to work their way up to Advanced Tracking they first need to level up their skill...but beyond that, they also have to find the trainer who can teach them the Advanced version of that skill. 

The vast majority of Avanced Trainers are not found in the major cities. Instead, they are out in the world, in the backwater outposts, front lines, caverns, ruins, mountains, forests, canyons, and wilds of the game. Our internal estimation is that roughly 85% of the advanced abilities you can learn in the game will be found outside of the major cities. 

The only way to find these trainers is to have a group capable of exploring the wilds and uncovering them in the first place. And also hoping that you have the prerequisite skills, statistics, faction, and beyond to train with them in the first place. 

Advancement is the result of hard work, given out for achievement, not simply for existing. If you want six-pack abs you have to be prepared to spend a few hours per day in the gym, as well as elminate the garbage from your diet. You don't get ripped by sitting on your ass all day long. 

All characters can be broken down into two Archetypes that you select at the start of your saga. 

Adventurer

The Adventurer Archetype is someone who is comfortable making a living by the skill of their martial abilities, by the sweat of their brow, and by the strength of their arm. They are comfortable in city, world and dungeon environments, and make up the backbone of any adventuring party making its way out beyond the safety of a city or outpost.

Examples of Adventurer Archetypes are Warriors, Thieves, Rangers, Bards, Monks, etc.

Scholar

The Scholar Archetype is someone who is more comfortable making a living with their scholarly abilities, through countless hours of study and research into ancient texts, runes, hieroglyphs and the various relics left behind from The Great War and the years when magic was still a part of the world and the Adepts still roamed the land keeping peace and aiding those in need.

Scholarly Archetypes are able to manipulate relics left behind from before the Great War, activating powers on items through the translation of those very same texts, runes, hieroglyphs and symbols. Scrolls, weapons, armor, old tomes, wands, statues, all fall under the review of a scholar's studious ways.

Scholars provide a support role within groups and are vital components to the ensured survival of a party. They can fill either heal/cure-based roles, utility slots, or damage-dealing roles based upon gear and skill selections.

The scholar's ability to translate ancient texts, languages and symbols also gives them a unique advantage in dungeon settings where certain areas of dungeons will remain forever hidden unless you have a scholar with the relevant skills in your party who can decipher texts to unseal ancient doors locked for centuries, sarcophagi holding the relics of the dead for countless millennia,  and to uncover other hidden mysteries, such as how to trigger an ancient well of resurrection or teleportation....


Combat, Survival, and The World Outside of Cities

The Saga of Lucimia is a game where tactical combat is the only way to move forward. There is zero tank-and-spank, face-roll-on-the-keyboard-to-win content in our game. Instead, we are going back to the basics where crowd control, mob placement, and strategic combat win the day. 

Utility is the key to every group, especially in the depths of a dungeon. And since magic is non-existent during Volume I, there are no clerics or characters who can heal or cast spells during combat. The only way to do so is through the use of relics.
 
Which means there are no in-combat spells or heals outside of those relics which allow for such spells to be cast. Players who have achieved such relics through quests and exploration of the world will be highly sought-after in groups. The same goes for Scholars and Adventurers who have come across magic weapons and armor which allow them to transcend the mundane. 

Which also means combat is extremely tactical. With no in-combat heals, every hitpoint counts. Especially since we are using a D&D-style of stats + hitpoints where there is zero bloat. You won't see players with 10k hitpoints in our world; instead, you'll see a standard 20 - 40 to start with, and 150-300 at the end-game via the use of relic items and sets of gear.  

Which means it is very much a reality to find yourself getting one-shotted if you are a squishy character who doesn't pay attention to where you are standing during combat, or you have a "bad tank" who doesn't place mobs properly. And no, there won't be flashy red glowing AOE reticles painted on the ground showing you where mob abilities are going to land. You'll have to figure that out through good old fashioned trial and error.

Strategizing your pulls and ensuring that you have plenty of crowd control is vital to your group's survival. On top of that, you'll need to be able to lock down any fleeing mobs, plus control the placement of the mobs during each encounter to ensure that mobs stay focused on the tanks and not wailing on the support classes who have limited mitigation and armor class, as well as fewer hitpoints. 

Relics can also be game-changing items. For example, teleportation in the Saga of Lucimia does not exist, at least not as a spell during Volume I. A player who has a transportation relic can literally become one of the most powerful players in the game world on his or her server, because he can suddenly travel instantly across great distances. Imagine a guild with a player who can transport raid groups across the world in an instant, while the rest of the players rely on the limited fast-travel options scattered between outposts and cities. 

Healing will largely take place within Encampments via the use of bandages, potions, and good old fashioned regeneration... unless players have relics which can afford them healing. Every group has the ability to set up a Camp during their adventures. These act as waypoints for the group during their adventures outside of the major cities and outposts, and it is here that you can set up a campfire, apply bandages, mend wounds, regenerate your hitpoints, repair your armor, cook food, and beyond. 

There are skills and abilities related to Encampments. Scholars will be able to place wards and traps depending on their ablities/relics, as well as Thief-Archetypes, or Ranger-Archetypes. This will help ward off danger during downtime when you are healing up and mending armor/weapons. 

There are no City Recall abilities in our game, and fast travel options are extremely limited outside of city-to-city or outpost-to-city options (none of which are completely safe; random encounters absolutely exist in our game). Encampments play a vital role in the survival of your group because they act as your group's headquarters during your time out in the field away from the outposts and cities.

Someone has to leave for the night? Emergency room because someone's kid fell and broke their arm, or there's a school play, or work, or movie night with the spouse? They'll be logging back in to the Caravan waypoint the next session. Group needs to break for the weekend? You'll want to set up an Encampment and place your wards/etc. while you log out. More on the Camps & Carvans system here.

When you set out on a campaign, you'll be heading out in a Caravan, which consists of a wagon or two of supplies, plus pack mules and horses. Which, by the way, can be killed. And the only way to get new mounts is to either have a Train Animal ability, or find another player who can train animals and also knows where to find them, or breeds them to sell to other players in the first place. 

Defending your Caravan on the way to the dungeon, not to mention during your adventures, as well as on the way back to the city with all of your hard-earned spoils, is part of the experience. Just as much as you want to haul your well-earned spoils back to town, there are bandits and other dangers in the wilds which will be waiting to take those spoils from you if you aren't strong enough to defend yourselves.

The Encampment + Caravan are vital to your survival in the wild. It is important to have a well-balanced group who can defend, as well as restock and repair the Caravan in between outposts and cities. Skills such as carpentry, leatherworking, armorsmithing, skinning, cooking, and beyond are required for survival in the wilds. If you are three weeks into the depths of a dungeon, you'll need someone along who can repair your armor, mend the broken axle on the wagon, make new potions and food, and tend to the wounds of both players and mounts. 

Since you can't simply recall back to a city every hour or so via the use of an ability, the only way to repair armor or restock your supplies while out on a campaign is either via your own skills or those of your allies. The only way to survive is by working together as a team. 

Gear plays a major role in your ability to survive, as do your character abilities. Relic armor and weapons and gear allow you to transcend mere human strength, dexterity, speed and abilities, and the only way to aquire relic gear is through exploration into the depths of ancient ruins and dungeons, which in turn requires a group for you to conquer. The only way to achieve is by working together as a team.

Community, and your ability to work together and play well with others, is the only way to move forward in The Saga of Lucimia. From the game forums, to the taverns and cities and outposts, to the in-game chat channels, to guilds and static groups, everything is about community and your ability to work within a team. 

What Are We Here For

If you've been following us for the past year since we started this journey back in March of 2014, you know that we've been dedicated to building this game in our spare time outside of our day jobs. We've assembled 12 team members since that time, and we've come a long way. 

We've been 100% transparent with our followers along the way, and have talked about our opinions on the current state of crowdfunding on a few different occassions, such as in this blog post and during the Twitch chat video below with producers Tim Anderson and Giovanni Martello.

Rather than rely on other people, we are funding this game out of our own pockets. We aren’t here on Indiegogo because we need your money. We are doing it because our community voted and asked us to. There are a lot of people out there (far more than we ever anticipated!) who actually WANT to help us fund this game, which has completely blown our minds!

Your support has been overwhelming. We had planned on working on this game throughout 2014, 2015, 2016, and launching in 2017 without ever seeing a dime of anyone else’s money, simply working on this in our spare time outside of our day jobs, and funding it out of our own pockets.

But your support has shown us that some of you want to help us with the costs, and that’s amazing. So after the vote, we decided to go ahead and do a small Indiegogo to let those of you who want to support us do so.


As you can see, we aren't doing an all-or-nothing campaign. We are instead doing a flexible funding campaign. That’s because we aren’t a “we need 800,000 USD to build this game or we all go home and don’t build it” group of developers.

Instead, we are a “we are already building this game in our spare time, using our own money, and if you want to help support us, then hell yes” group of people.

The 5,000 USD we are looking for here will mitigate server costs for the upcoming alpha server that you backers will be testing with us, as well as the rest of our needed Unity assets + some legal fees. 

But here's something you should know. Indiegogo & Paypal (or Credit Card) each take about 4% of funds we raise IF WE MAKE OUR GOAL. If we don't, they take a whopping 13% (combined). So obviously if we hit our target goal of 5k, it's better. 

And if we do hit it, we've got a ton of stretch goals already in place. 


THE CHEERLEADER - 25 USD

The "Mutton Again?" tshirt from artist Joseph Bennett, plus two months of access to our alpha servers (same as our Length of Rope shirts).

THE SUPPORTER - 35 USD

The "Closed Until Alpha" hoodie from artist Nick Lepperd, plus two months of access to our alpha servers (same as our Length of Rope hoodies).

THE ADVENTURER - 40 USD

Digital copy of Volume I as well as Total Access to all alpha and beta stages as they are available.

THE EXPLORER - 75 USD

Volume I, Total Access, and Starter Relic Weapon (selectable by archetype)

THE FOUNDER - 125 USD

Volume I, Total Access, Starter Relic Weapon + Boots (selectable by archetype), Founder Title

THE PATRON - 200 USD

Volume I, Total Access, Starter Relic Weapon + Boots , Patron Title, monthly Dev Tavern Newsletter featuring special behind-the-scenes access to what the developer team is working on.

THE COLLECTOR - 300 USD

Volume I, Total Access, Starter Relic Weapon + Boots, Collector Title, monthly Dev Tavern Newsletter access, digital Collector's Edition with behind-the-scenes artwork and development tidbits via a PDF, as well as a physical cloth map + loot bag. 

If You Don't Need The Money, Why Indiegogo?

Good question. First and foremost, we are here because our community voted and asked us to. 

Secondly, for those of you who don't know who we are, building an MMORPG is a massive venture. We currently have 12 team members. We are splitting the costs of game development between the team for things like art assets from the Unity store, as well as legal costs, server costs, and beyond. 

Just because our day jobs pay our cost of living/bills/put food on the table for our family, doesn't mean we have money coming out of our ears. There are a lot of costs inherent in building a game of this nature. 

Thankfully, because our team is working from home, remotely around the world, we don't have the overhead of an office space or the overall costs associated with renting a building and then needing to build/buy rigs for everyone and the like. 

Plus, because we all have day jobs, we don't need to go to Kickstarter or Indiegogo and ask for 1+ million dollars so that we can earn a salary while building our game. We're more than willing to work for free in our spare time, building up our hobby and passion into a business that will eventually become our full-time jobs after launch.

However, art assets, licenses, legal fees, and beyond, all start to add up. For example, when we start looking at the art assets we are purchasing from the Unity store, it's very easy to go from 25 bucks here, 60 bucks there, 15 bucks there, 45 dollars there, and suddenly find ourselves in a situation where we are spending 500 - 1000 USD in a week to pick up new assets or code structures that the team needs to use to customize with our own unique twists. 

We estimate there are around 10,000 USD worth of fees that need to be taken care of in 2015 in between assets we need to purchase + legal fees + licenses and beyond. We'll be spending money out of our own pockets as we have it, but we will also be leveraging crowdfunding from our dedicated fans to help us mitigate those costs as much as possible. 


Risks & Challenges

None, really. We're already building this game, regardless if anyone backs us or not. Head on over to our website. Check out our YouTube channel. You'll see that we've been plugging away the past year without a dime from anyone, and we've said since day one we will never be asking for people to pay our salaries for us until we have a finished product. 

Your financial backing helps us mitigate our out-of-pocket expenses, but at no point will a lack of backing from outside sources halt our game development. We make enough money with our day jobs to keep on going until we release Volume I in 2017, so there's no risk as far as we are concerned. 

That being said, if you guys want to donate and pledge and help our team actually make money while developing this game, I don't see a reason not to run campaigns like this Indiegogo project, or the private crowdfunding that will be coming to our website later in 2015, so long as the desire is there from our community to help our team out in the development of this game. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute financially, and we get that, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Share this campaign around to your friends, family, business associates, and anyone you can think of that would enjoy a group-based MMORPG that is taking it back to the classic era.
story_txt:
The Saga of Lucimia
 
Welcome to The Saga of Lucimia, a high-fantasy, group-based MMORPG that hearkens back to a time when players worked together to achieve goals that were greater than what they could achieve on their own.  
A time when teamwork, friendship and community meant more than "everyman" games chock-full of single-serving, on-the-rails questlines designed to take you to max level in a matter of days in such a way that you never have to interact with another player to achieve the "end game". 
No mini-maps. No quest hubs. Zero solo content. 3-4 man overland content, 8-man dungeons, and multi-group raids. No flashing icons over the heads of NPCs telling you who to talk to or where to go, no glowing trails leading you from quest objective to quest objective. 
Languages, factions, ruins, cities, dungeons, and more. A massive world to explore, and a classless, skill-based game where you create your own story with your friends and allies. 
Explore emergent gameplay in a world where the players determine the hot spots, the best places to hunt, their favorite dungeons, routes to and from cities, camp spots, and beyond. With zero single-player storylines guiding you or funneling you from Point A to Point B. Sandbox, not themepark. 
Welcome back to the days of group-based gaming. 


The Fellowship of the Ring was not just one character. Jason had his Argonauts. Zeus went up against The Titans alongside The Olympians. History and mythology is full of examples of epic battles waged in the battle of good versus evil…and none of them are fought single-handed.
Modern-day television enraptures this essence as well, with shows like Firefly, Lost, and The Walking Dead all showcasing a team of players facing up against the odds. And we’ve seen it over the years as well; Star Trek, Babylon 5, Battlestar Galactica (both the original and re-imagined), Stargate and beyond.
The greatest adventures are undertaken by groups. The greatest challenges can only be overcome with allies. The greatest rewards come from deeds performed alongside your peers. Dragons aren’t slain by lone heroes; it takes a team of well-oiled champions battling together to bring it down…and then share in the spoils of war together.

If you grew up on Dungeons and Dragons, Ultima Online, EverQuest, and Vanilla World of Warcraft, than you know exactly what we are creating: a group-based game where the only way to move forward is by making strategic progression with allies by your side. 

Our World 
 
Get back to basics with a challenge-based MMORPG focusing on epic adventure the moment you step outside the safety of the city walls. 
This is more than just a game. Ours is a living, breathing world with a rich, deep texture of history and lore, where danger lurks around every corner and adventure awaits the moment you step out of any door.
Magic is non-existent at this point of the world, which is where Volume I picks up, 500 years after the Archemage Chaldeon took the Book of Knowledge into hiding, deeming mankind unfit to handle the responsibility that came with having access to great power. 

Now, all that is left behind are the architectural masterpieces the Elder Races once created, as well as dungeons, scrolls, relics and books that the Scholar’s Guild protects at all costs in a vain attempt to retain as much mastery over their once-great power as possible. Over time, however, their ability to control the relics, decipher the runes and texts and tap into the once-powerful magic, is fading.
You are born into a world where magic is nothing more than a distant memory. Mankind gets things done with the sweat of their brow and with their own two hands. Master Scholars are able to augment the day-to-day aspects of living with various relics, and adventurers with the relevant understanding of runes, lore and the ancient texts can tap into the hidden power of armor and weapons, but the days of Adepts and magic and spells and Elder races are nothing more than myths and legends shown in ancient paintings and faded scrolls and books and stumbled across in long-forgotten dungeons.

We have planned 40 overland zones, 10 dungeons, and 6 cities to explore within The Saga of Lucimia upon completion. And while there is an underlying main storyline that will take you through the game world as you follow along the events of Volume I in The Story So Far, leading you through forests, mountains, ancient dungeons and beyond to uncover the resting place of the Book of Knowledge and bring magic back to the realm (Volume II), the quest content is 100% optional. 

Remember: sandbox, not themepark.If you want to skip the major storylines and quests of the game and just go out there and grind dungeons and overland content and raids with your friends, that's your choice. But if you also enjoy epic storylines, there are multiple chains that you can follow along with, and a rich backstory + in-game lore to immerse yourself in. The main storyline will lead you through small group content (3-4 players) in the overland zones, into the depths of tombs, dungeons, and ruins where 6-8 players are required, and on to multi-group raids where only the truly dedicated will be able to follow along and achieve epic weapons and armor sets as a result of their investment. There are also major storylines related to the overall world and the areas, cities, and outposts. Think the Coldain Ring and Shawl quests from EverQuest. Every questline we are creating is an epic, multi-stage, multi-group campaign meant to span weeks and months. There is no such thing as a single-serving or single-stage quest in the Saga of Lucimia. And every single moment is based around challenge.

What Is Challenge?

If you make the decision to leave the safety of town and its guards, it’s not a decision you should be making lightly. You need to prepare for an adventure that will take multiple game sessions to complete. 
Zones will take hours to multiple game sessions to cross, depending on if you stay on the path or head off into unmarked territory. Dungeons will take weeks to months to complete. Ours is not a game to be played in five minute chunks of time. Ours is a world where you invest yourself just as much as in the real world, and meet up with your friends, family, and allies for scheduled game sessions, just like a D&D campaign around the coffee table. 
You need a balanced group of adventurers to handle whatever you might come across in the wild. You need gear. You need supplies. Bandages. Potions. Scrolls. A pack mule and mounts. Wagons. Extra leather, wood, steel, sharpening stones, tools, and rope. Never leave home without a good length of rope.
It’s an excursion, not an afternoon stroll down to the river to pick daffodils for your sweetheart or mum.
Think the Mines of Moria; we want every dungeon and adventure our players encounter to be on par with what The Fellowship encountered while being forced to skip the pass and head into the mines.
That being said, we understand the limitations of Real Life. Sometimes you can't commit to lengthy gaming sessions day in and day out. You've got a job, spouse, kids, other hobbies, and other commitments. That's what mechanics such as our Camps & Caravans system are being designed for.
Beyond that, we're adding other mechanics to up the ante. For example, there won't be mini-maps in this game. You'll be navigating based on your own ability to figure out where you are in the world or a given zone. You'll be able to find maps for cities that you can store in your inventory and open up to help you navigate the streets, but there won't be a glowing dot with a "You Are Here" marker; you'll still need to be able to read the map and figure out where you are in the city.
There will also be NPC-dropped maps that are part of quest chains, as well as those given to you by NPCs as part of quests, but those won't be linked to a mini-map. Instead, it will be based on your ability to read the map in real-time and navigate the world using descriptions and landmarks in conjunction with those maps...if any exist in the first place for whatever it is you are looking for.
And yes, there will be corpse runs; if you die in the wild, your gear will remain on your corpse and it will be up to you (and your friends) to work your way back to where your corpse remains to recover your gear and continue your adventure.

    

The Game
The Saga of Lucimia MMORPG is a group-based, classless game where there are no levels. Instead, we are using a skill-based character system where you can create whatever type of Player Character you want. 

Your selection of skills defines your playstyle and your class. Upon character creation you have the option to choose which skills will define your character during your time in the unfolding saga, customizing your character based upon your own unique combination of skills.
The content of the world can only be overcome by balanced groups of Player Characters leveraging a wide array of skills throughout the Archetypes. The challenges you face are not merely combat-based. Mechanical and magical traps, locks, doorways, and more abound in our world, and if you lack the skills to detect/unlock/overcome those challenges, your progress will come to a halt. 
Dungeons have entire sections dedicated to mechanical traps and doorways that can only be overcome by player with Thief abilities. Other sections are locked away behind magical doorways and rune traps that only a trained Scholar can bypass or detect. If you walk into a dungeon with purely Adventurer Archetypes, you may very well pass by entire wings without even knowing they exist. Or walk into a cavern in the middle of the mountains and never even detect the dungeon entrance in the first place.
Or pass by that tunnel that rises above you and never know that there is an entire wing above the party, because your characters lack climbing skills or tools, and because no one was paying attention and only looking forward. 



While you can create a character from scratch and choose your own skills to start, there is also a list of pre-designed Archetype builds that most long-term gamers and table-top players will be familiar with, such as Monk, Ranger, Thief, Bard and beyond. These builds have pre-selected skill combinations that best define them based upon lore and the type of character they represent. There are also sub-builds, such as the Archer version of the Warrior, or the Assassin version of the Thief.
In addition, these pre-built Archetypes have special advanced abilities assigned to them. Such as a Ranger build having Advanced Tracking. While a player just starting out can choose Tracking at the beginner level, if they want to work their way up to Advanced Tracking they first need to level up their skill...but beyond that, they also have to find the trainer who can teach them the Advanced version of that skill. 
The vast majority of Avanced Trainers are not found in the major cities. Instead, they are out in the world, in the backwater outposts, front lines, caverns, ruins, mountains, forests, canyons, and wilds of the game. Our internal estimation is that roughly 85% of the advanced abilities you can learn in the game will be found outside of the major cities. 
The only way to find these trainers is to have a group capable of exploring the wilds and uncovering them in the first place. And also hoping that you have the prerequisite skills, statistics, faction, and beyond to train with them in the first place. 
Advancement is the result of hard work, given out for achievement, not simply for existing. If you want six-pack abs you have to be prepared to spend a few hours per day in the gym, as well as elminate the garbage from your diet. You don't get ripped by sitting on your ass all day long. 
All characters can be broken down into two Archetypes that you select at the start of your saga. 


Adventurer
The Adventurer Archetype is someone who is comfortable making a living by the skill of their martial abilities, by the sweat of their brow, and by the strength of their arm. They are comfortable in city, world and dungeon environments, and make up the backbone of any adventuring party making its way out beyond the safety of a city or outpost.
Examples of Adventurer Archetypes are Warriors, Thieves, Rangers, Bards, Monks, etc.
Scholar
The Scholar Archetype is someone who is more comfortable making a living with their scholarly abilities, through countless hours of study and research into ancient texts, runes, hieroglyphs and the various relics left behind from The Great War and the years when magic was still a part of the world and the Adepts still roamed the land keeping peace and aiding those in need.
Scholarly Archetypes are able to manipulate relics left behind from before the Great War, activating powers on items through the translation of those very same texts, runes, hieroglyphs and symbols. Scrolls, weapons, armor, old tomes, wands, statues, all fall under the review of a scholar's studious ways.
Scholars provide a support role within groups and are vital components to the ensured survival of a party. They can fill either heal/cure-based roles, utility slots, or damage-dealing roles based upon gear and skill selections.
The scholar's ability to translate ancient texts, languages and symbols also gives them a unique advantage in dungeon settings where certain areas of dungeons will remain forever hidden unless you have a scholar with the relevant skills in your party who can decipher texts to unseal ancient doors locked for centuries, sarcophagi holding the relics of the dead for countless millennia,  and to uncover other hidden mysteries, such as how to trigger an ancient well of resurrection or teleportation....

Combat, Survival, and The World Outside of Cities
The Saga of Lucimia is a game where tactical combat is the only way to move forward. There is zero tank-and-spank, face-roll-on-the-keyboard-to-win content in our game. Instead, we are going back to the basics where crowd control, mob placement, and strategic combat win the day. 

Utility is the key to every group, especially in the depths of a dungeon. And since magic is non-existent during Volume I, there are no clerics or characters who can heal or cast spells during combat. The only way to do so is through the use of relics.
 
Which means there are no in-combat spells or heals outside of those relics which allow for such spells to be cast. Players who have achieved such relics through quests and exploration of the world will be highly sought-after in groups. The same goes for Scholars and Adventurers who have come across magic weapons and armor which allow them to transcend the mundane. 

Which also means combat is extremely tactical. With no in-combat heals, every hitpoint counts. Especially since we are using a D&D-style of stats + hitpoints where there is zero bloat. You won't see players with 10k hitpoints in our world; instead, you'll see a standard 20 - 40 to start with, and 150-300 at the end-game via the use of relic items and sets of gear.  

Which means it is very much a reality to find yourself getting one-shotted if you are a squishy character who doesn't pay attention to where you are standing during combat, or you have a "bad tank" who doesn't place mobs properly. And no, there won't be flashy red glowing AOE reticles painted on the ground showing you where mob abilities are going to land. You'll have to figure that out through good old fashioned trial and error.


Strategizing your pulls and ensuring that you have plenty of crowd control is vital to your group's survival. On top of that, you'll need to be able to lock down any fleeing mobs, plus control the placement of the mobs during each encounter to ensure that mobs stay focused on the tanks and not wailing on the support classes who have limited mitigation and armor class, as well as fewer hitpoints. 

Relics can also be game-changing items. For example, teleportation in the Saga of Lucimia does not exist, at least not as a spell during Volume I. A player who has a transportation relic can literally become one of the most powerful players in the game world on his or her server, because he can suddenly travel instantly across great distances. Imagine a guild with a player who can transport raid groups across the world in an instant, while the rest of the players rely on the limited fast-travel options scattered between outposts and cities. 

Healing will largely take place within Encampments via the use of bandages, potions, and good old fashioned regeneration... unless players have relics which can afford them healing. Every group has the ability to set up a Camp during their adventures. These act as waypoints for the group during their adventures outside of the major cities and outposts, and it is here that you can set up a campfire, apply bandages, mend wounds, regenerate your hitpoints, repair your armor, cook food, and beyond. 

There are skills and abilities related to Encampments. Scholars will be able to place wards and traps depending on their ablities/relics, as well as Thief-Archetypes, or Ranger-Archetypes. This will help ward off danger during downtime when you are healing up and mending armor/weapons. 

There are no City Recall abilities in our game, and fast travel options are extremely limited outside of city-to-city or outpost-to-city options (none of which are completely safe; random encounters absolutely exist in our game). Encampments play a vital role in the survival of your group because they act as your group's headquarters during your time out in the field away from the outposts and cities.

Someone has to leave for the night? Emergency room because someone's kid fell and broke their arm, or there's a school play, or work, or movie night with the spouse? They'll be logging back in to the Caravan waypoint the next session. Group needs to break for the weekend? You'll want to set up an Encampment and place your wards/etc. while you log out. More on the Camps & Carvans system here.


When you set out on a campaign, you'll be heading out in a Caravan, which consists of a wagon or two of supplies, plus pack mules and horses. Which, by the way, can be killed. And the only way to get new mounts is to either have a Train Animal ability, or find another player who can train animals and also knows where to find them, or breeds them to sell to other players in the first place. 


Defending your Caravan on the way to the dungeon, not to mention during your adventures, as well as on the way back to the city with all of your hard-earned spoils, is part of the experience. Just as much as you want to haul your well-earned spoils back to town, there are bandits and other dangers in the wilds which will be waiting to take those spoils from you if you aren't strong enough to defend yourselves.

The Encampment + Caravan are vital to your survival in the wild. It is important to have a well-balanced group who can defend, as well as restock and repair the Caravan in between outposts and cities. Skills such as carpentry, leatherworking, armorsmithing, skinning, cooking, and beyond are required for survival in the wilds. If you are three weeks into the depths of a dungeon, you'll need someone along who can repair your armor, mend the broken axle on the wagon, make new potions and food, and tend to the wounds of both players and mounts. 

Since you can't simply recall back to a city every hour or so via the use of an ability, the only way to repair armor or restock your supplies while out on a campaign is either via your own skills or those of your allies. The only way to survive is by working together as a team. 


Gear plays a major role in your ability to survive, as do your character abilities. Relic armor and weapons and gear allow you to transcend mere human strength, dexterity, speed and abilities, and the only way to aquire relic gear is through exploration into the depths of ancient ruins and dungeons, which in turn requires a group for you to conquer. The only way to achieve is by working together as a team.



Community, and your ability to work together and play well with others, is the only way to move forward in The Saga of Lucimia. From the game forums, to the taverns and cities and outposts, to the in-game chat channels, to guilds and static groups, everything is about community and your ability to work within a team. 

What Are We Here For
If you've been following us for the past year since we started this journey back in March of 2014, you know that we've been dedicated to building this game in our spare time outside of our day jobs. We've assembled 12 team members since that time, and we've come a long way. 

We've been 100% transparent with our followers along the way, and have talked about our opinions on the current state of crowdfunding on a few different occassions, such as in this blog post and during the Twitch chat video below with producers Tim Anderson and Giovanni Martello.



Rather than rely on other people, we are funding this game out of our own pockets. We aren’t here on Indiegogo because we need your money. We are doing it because our community voted and asked us to. There are a lot of people out there (far more than we ever anticipated!) who actually WANT to help us fund this game, which has completely blown our minds!
Your support has been overwhelming. We had planned on working on this game throughout 2014, 2015, 2016, and launching in 2017 without ever seeing a dime of anyone else’s money, simply working on this in our spare time outside of our day jobs, and funding it out of our own pockets.
But your support has shown us that some of you want to help us with the costs, and that’s amazing. So after the vote, we decided to go ahead and do a small Indiegogo to let those of you who want to support us do so.


As you can see, we aren't doing an all-or-nothing campaign. We are instead doing a flexible funding campaign. That’s because we aren’t a “we need 800,000 USD to build this game or we all go home and don’t build it” group of developers.
Instead, we are a “we are already building this game in our spare time, using our own money, and if you want to help support us, then hell yes” group of people.
The 5,000 USD we are looking for here will mitigate server costs for the upcoming alpha server that you backers will be testing with us, as well as the rest of our needed Unity assets + some legal fees. 
But here's something you should know. Indiegogo & Paypal (or Credit Card) each take about 4% of funds we raise IF WE MAKE OUR GOAL. If we don't, they take a whopping 13% (combined). So obviously if we hit our target goal of 5k, it's better. 



And if we do hit it, we've got a ton of stretch goals already in place. 




THE CHEERLEADER - 25 USD
The "Mutton Again?" tshirt from artist Joseph Bennett, plus two months of access to our alpha servers (same as our Length of Rope shirts).
THE SUPPORTER - 35 USD
The "Closed Until Alpha" hoodie from artist Nick Lepperd, plus two months of access to our alpha servers (same as our Length of Rope hoodies).
THE ADVENTURER - 40 USD
Digital copy of Volume I as well as Total Access to all alpha and beta stages as they are available.
THE EXPLORER - 75 USD
Volume I, Total Access, and Starter Relic Weapon (selectable by archetype)
THE FOUNDER - 125 USD
Volume I, Total Access, Starter Relic Weapon + Boots (selectable by archetype), Founder Title
THE PATRON - 200 USD
Volume I, Total Access, Starter Relic Weapon + Boots , Patron Title, monthly Dev Tavern Newsletter featuring special behind-the-scenes access to what the developer team is working on.
THE COLLECTOR - 300 USD
Volume I, Total Access, Starter Relic Weapon + Boots, Collector Title, monthly Dev Tavern Newsletter access, digital Collector's Edition with behind-the-scenes artwork and development tidbits via a PDF, as well as a physical cloth map + loot bag. 



If You Don't Need The Money, Why Indiegogo?

Good question. First and foremost, we are here because our community voted and asked us to. 
Secondly, for those of you who don't know who we are, building an MMORPG is a massive venture. We currently have 12 team members. We are splitting the costs of game development between the team for things like art assets from the Unity store, as well as legal costs, server costs, and beyond. 
Just because our day jobs pay our cost of living/bills/put food on the table for our family, doesn't mean we have money coming out of our ears. There are a lot of costs inherent in building a game of this nature. 
Thankfully, because our team is working from home, remotely around the world, we don't have the overhead of an office space or the overall costs associated with renting a building and then needing to build/buy rigs for everyone and the like. 
Plus, because we all have day jobs, we don't need to go to Kickstarter or Indiegogo and ask for 1+ million dollars so that we can earn a salary while building our game. We're more than willing to work for free in our spare time, building up our hobby and passion into a business that will eventually become our full-time jobs after launch.
However, art assets, licenses, legal fees, and beyond, all start to add up. For example, when we start looking at the art assets we are purchasing from the Unity store, it's very easy to go from 25 bucks here, 60 bucks there, 15 bucks there, 45 dollars there, and suddenly find ourselves in a situation where we are spending 500 - 1000 USD in a week to pick up new assets or code structures that the team needs to use to customize with our own unique twists. 
We estimate there are around 10,000 USD worth of fees that need to be taken care of in 2015 in between assets we need to purchase + legal fees + licenses and beyond. We'll be spending money out of our own pockets as we have it, but we will also be leveraging crowdfunding from our dedicated fans to help us mitigate those costs as much as possible. 


    Risks & Challenges None, really. We're already building this game, regardless if anyone backs us or not. Head on over to our website. Check out our YouTube channel. You'll see that we've been plugging away the past year without a dime from anyone, and we've said since day one we will never be asking for people to pay our salaries for us until we have a finished product. 
Your financial backing helps us mitigate our out-of-pocket expenses, but at no point will a lack of backing from outside sources halt our game development. We make enough money with our day jobs to keep on going until we release Volume I in 2017, so there's no risk as far as we are concerned. 
That being said, if you guys want to donate and pledge and help our team actually make money while developing this game, I don't see a reason not to run campaigns like this Indiegogo project, or the private crowdfunding that will be coming to our website later in 2015, so long as the desire is there from our community to help our team out in the development of this game. 
    
Other Ways You Can HelpSome people just can't contribute financially, and we get that, but that doesn't mean you can't help! Share this campaign around to your friends, family, business associates, and anyone you can think of that would enjoy a group-based MMORPG that is taking it back to the classic era.

C-Board is a clipboard with dimensions 320x230mm made of 100% 3K C200T2 carbon fiber fabric. It features a strong metal clip to hold your A4 papers. Both sides of C-Board have a high gloss ultra smooth surface.

What is Carbon Fiber?
story_txt:
C-Board is a clipboard with dimensions 320x230mm made of 100% 3K C200T2 carbon fiber fabric. It features a strong metal clip to hold your A4 papers. Both sides of C-Board have a high gloss ultra smooth surface.
What is Carbon Fiber?

Carbon fiber is made from very small strands of carbon that is woven into a fabric.  That fabric is then combined with epoxy resin and placed into a mold to create complex shapes or laid flat to create a sheet.
This combination of Carbon Fiber fabric and resin creates a composite material with a very high strength to weight ratio. It is often described as being stronger than steel yet lighter than aluminum.
Manufacturing Process
Carbon fiber fabrics are cut to pieces and placed inside the mold. More filler fabrics applied inside the mold above the first layer of carbon fiber. Last, more carbon fiber fabrics with same dimensions is place inside the mold on top of all the fabrics.
The next step is to apply a releasing film called peel-ply. That fabric act as a separator of the finished part (carbon fiber part) and the fabrics that added after carbon fiber fabrics.
Next fabric is the flow fabric. That fabric helps the epoxy resin to fill every corner of our mold.
Last, is the vacuum bagging film. This is the sealant bag that creates the vacuum needed to put pressure on our part inside the mold, with the help of a vacuum pump.
When we are ready with our vacuum sealant, epoxy resin enters the mold and infuses our entire pack of fabrics.
After some hours, the epoxy resin is cured and the carbon fiber part can be removed from our mold.
Next step is to trim the carbon fiber part to the final dimensions of the clipboard. Last, the metal clip is added on the carbon fiber clipboard with rivets.
The carbon fiber clipboard is manufactured with Vacuum Infusion Method.

 
The Vacuum Infusion Process (VIP) is a technique that uses vacuum pressure to drive resin into a laminate. Materials are laid dry into the mold and the vacuum is applied before resin is introduced into the mold. Once a complete vacuum is achieved, resin is literally sucked into the laminate via carefully placed tubing. This process is aided by an assortment of supplies and materials.
Vacuum infusion provides a number of improvements over traditionally vacuum bagged parts. These benefits include:
• Better fiber-to-resin ratio
• Very consistent resin usage
• Lightweight products
The properties of carbon fibers, such as high stiffness, high tensile strength, low weight, high chemical resistance, high temperature tolerance and low thermal expansion, make them very popular in aerospace, civil engineering, military, and motorsports, along with other competition sports.
Advantages of C-Board compared to other clipboards
·Lifetime usage
·Rip and crease resistant
·Retain shape and resist bending
·100% waterproof
Below you can see the strength of C-Board, weighting just 200gr.That’s 10kgs above C-Board.

 
Budget and timeline
Our current prototypes are created on rented equipment designed for punctual prototyping purposes. Our molds are not ready for anything close to a manufacturing volume.
We need the funds to purchase adequate tooling, exercise high-volume orders on raw materials/components and create the new manufacture-ready molds. These steps cannot be accomplished without adequate funding.
Your funds will help us implement a real production setup and give us the ability to bring this product on the market at a realistic price and guaranteed quality.


 

The complete first cycle from production until dispatch of the product is listed below.

 
More photos of C-Board










 

 

 
 The carbon fiber keyring can be seen below.

  
Risks and challenges
Molding technique
One of our major milestone was to develop a molding technique to highlight the carbon fiber, whilst keeping the mechanical properties of it. The technique we've developed allowed us to place the carbon fiber fabric in an aesthetic manner without wave distortion and without cutting the fabric to preserve its strength. 
Delivery Schedule 
Part of our work was to design a manufacturing process that could realistically produce large quantities of C-Boards without impairing the quality. The infusion molding technique, with hand-made molds and pre-cut fiber was part of the solution.
Perfection 
Our prototype is in continuous improvement. Our latest prototype is beyond your expectations as it features some more additional subtle features for both a better aesthetic and a smoother finish.
Your satisfaction 
We want to make sure that you will be happy with the product that you will receive from us. Our goal is to have you enjoy as much time as possible with your new item.

Thank you so much for checking out this project and for your support!

story:
What's Habilia?

Habilia is an innovative gaming platform. How is it innovative? In several ways:

  • It lets players take each other on for real money.
  • It rewards players' talent: if they are good players, they win the money they deserve.
  • It only allows SKILL games so the chance element is NEVER a factor in the game.
  • Developers, too, earn with Habilia: their games generate money every time a match is started.
  • Habilia is world wide and help remove geographical boundaries so that real gaming aficionados can enjoy new challenges and tournaments -- whatever their location.
  • Although still in its Beta phase, Habilia is compatible with iOS, Android, Amazon devices, Macs and PCs, smart TVs, and consoles. Its functionality and technology can even be applied to live challenges (e.g. a bike race or a marathon). Habilia can be applied to anything involving skill-based competitions.


What We Need & What You Get

Running a system like Habilia is very, very, very expensive. We have gathered together all our resources to purchase the infrastructure, servers, oh-so-costly legal services, but we cannot go past the Beta phase without you. The gaming market is a highly competitive one. The funds we receive will be used to promote Habilia in an almost fully-saturated market. This promotional activity requires LOTS of cash.

  • The money that is invested in the Habilia project will be used to enlarge and strengthen the system. We will spend the money on: marketing campaigns & product launch, new content acquisition, and user experience enhancement. This is how we will be using the funds whether or not we reach the goal.
  • Each and every contributor will be named in the credits section. In addition, depending on the amount donated, you can get Habilia-branded apparel, tech gadgets, gaming paraphernalia, and a golden name tag with your name engraved if you are one of the top contributors.

Why contribute?

Habilia is for true gaming aficionados. If you like playing games and show off your skills, you should not be prevented from doing so. Habilia makes sure that ONLY skill games appear on the platform. So you can enjoy a 100% legal, fun-packed experience and, why not, make friends from around the world. Indeed, Habilia is designed to have a vibrant community section where players can interact and get to know one the other.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, there are plenty of other ways you can effectively help us:

  • Use Indigogo share tools to share this campaign.
  • Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.
  • Make sure your friend circles get to know about us.
Thank you very much to all of you who have or are going to contribute!

PLEASE NOTE: The perks that include credits as well as physical goods will be delivered in two instalments: credits will be delivered in 14 days at most, whilst physical goods will be sent in mid April 2015. Once credited to a player account, Habilia Coins can be used right away.

story:
Perché?

Confronto nasce durante una giornata d'estate 2016, in un momento di noia. Mi chiedevo se potesse esistere un gioco competitivo e bilanciato senza creare delle vere e proprie carte, ma utilizzando le carte più famose al mondo, le carte da Poker!

Beh, a quanto pare, qualcosa è uscito fuori. "Confronto" si ispira molto ai tradizionali giochi di carte collezionabili ma  ne riduce drasticamente il prezzo (eliminando la componente collezionabile). Non voglio perdermi molto in chiacchiere, voglio che siate voi a decidere se il gioco vale o meno il vostro tempo, di seguito vi spiegherò il perché di questa campagna e poi vi illustrerò le regole.

Ma se posso giocare con delle normali carte da poker... che senso ha questa campagna?

Bene, questa domanda è più che giusta. Perché una persona dovrebbe pagare per giocare ad un gioco che è gratis?

Beh, se avete notato, io non chiedo decine di mila euro per completare la mia campagna, ma chiedo solo €2500 che serviranno a pagare la creazione di mazzi personalizzati, con esclusivi artwork per ogni carta e la stampa dei mai stessi. Solo questo! 

Le regole!

leggete questo PDF per l'ultima versione delle regole di gioco!
https://document.li/HfML

“Confronto!“ è un gioco di carte creato in estate 2016 giocabile facilmente con un solo mazzo da 54 carte francesi (da poker, per intenderci).
 

SCOPO DEL GIOCO

Lo scopo del gioco è ridurre i punti vita all’avversario a 0 tramite i “Confronti!”. Ogni giocatore ad inizio partita ha 21 punti vita.

PREPARAZIONE DEL GIOCO

Prendete un mazzo di 54 carte (52 + 2 Joker) e dividetelo in due mazzi, uno composto da tutte le carte con i semi rossi ed uno con tutte le carte con i semi neri. Poi, prendete un Joker a testa.

Prendete uno dei due mazzi (sono identici se non per i semi) e date l’altro al vostro avversario. Successivamente posizionate i mazzi alla vostra sinistra orizzontalmente.

Guardate la figura 1 per capire lo stato del campo.

IL CONFRONTO!

Eccoci giunti al fulcro del gioco: il “Confronto!”.

Esistono due tipi di “Confronto!”: il “Confronto!” diretto e il “Confronto!” contro un’ altra carta. Vediamo le fasi di battaglia.

Fase 1 - Dichiarazione di “Confronto!”:
ll giocatore, esclusivamente durante il suo turno, dichiara un “attacco” da                     parte di una delle sue carte sul terreno verso una specifica carta dell’avversario. Se l’avversario non ha carte sul terreno, il “Confronto!” diventa diretto.In questo caso passa al punto 1.1; altrimenti, passa al punto 2.

Fase 1.1 - Ace SpAce:

Il giocatore avversario decide se usare o meno un Asso, sempre che ne abbia uno in mano. Se l’avversario non ha Assi in mano o non vuole giocarlo passa alla fase 1.2 per terminare il “Confronto!”.

Se l’asso viene giocato, sia questo che la carta che ha dichiarato il “Confronto!” viengono posizionati nella rispettiva pila degli scarti.

Ricorda! In caso in cui la carta che dichiara il “Confronto!” sia un Doppio, esso non viene spaccato completamente ma viene privato solo di una delle due carte, dopo, potrà attaccare nuovamente.

Dopo questa fase, il giocatore di turno può continuare ad attaccare con le sue altre carte. Quindi la fase di battaglia viene riavviata. 

( Ricorda, puoi anche giocare un Ace Breaker).
 

Fase 1.2 - Confronto diretto - Danno

Ora sottrai il valore della carta a quello dei punti vita del tuo avversario. Ricorda, ogni giocatore ad inizio partita ha 21 punti.

Dopo che il danno è andato a buon fine, taglia (distruggi) la carta che ha appena confrontato direttamente e posizionala in cima alla pila degli scarti.

Ora è ancora il tuo turno, puoi attaccare nuovamente, in tal caso, la fase di battaglia si riavvia.
 

Fase 2: - Ace SpAce:

Il giocatore avversario decide se usare o meno un Asso, sempre che ne abbia uno in mano. Se l’avversario non ha Assi in mano o non vuole giocarlo, passa alla fase 2.1 per contunuare il confronto. 

Se l’asso viene giocato, il giocatore che ha dichiarato il “Confronto!” non infligge danno all’avversario. Al termine di questa fase l’asso, la carta che ha dichiarato il “Confronto!” e la carta su cui è stato dichiarato il “Confronto!” vengono posizionate nella rispettiva pila degli scarti.

Ricorda! In caso in cui la carta che dichiara il confronto sia un Doppio, esso non viene spaccato completamente ma viene privato solo di una delle due carte, dopo, potrà attaccare nuovamente.

Dopo questa fase, il giocatore di turno può continuare ad attaccare con le sue altre carte. Quindi la fase di battaglia viene riavviata. 

( Ricorda, puoi anche giocare un Ace Breaker).

Fase 2.1: - “Confronto!” tra due carte.
Attenzione! un doppio privato della sua metà (eccetto il caso in cui l’avversario ha usato un Asso) non può riconfrontarsi nello stesso turno. Ricorda: una volta che hai dichiarato il primo “Confronto!”, non puoi spostare o posizionare nessuna carta, neanche i “K” o gli “Assi”.

Bene! è ora di confrontarsi! 

Se il giocatore che ha dichiarato il “Confronto!” lo ha fatto verso un carta in posizione Cavaliera -> vai alla fase 2.1.1

Se il giocatore che ha dichiarato il “Confronto!” lo ha fatto verso un carta in posizione Mistero -> vai alla fase 2.1.2

Se il giocatore che ha dichiarato il “Confronto!” lo ha fatto verso un carta in posizione Scudo -> vai alla fase 2.1.3

"Confronto! Competitive"

Se avete letto il PDF, avrete sicuramente notato una variane del gioco chiamata "Confronto! Competitive".

Per questa versione ho deciso di creare alcune carte speciali, ogni carta ha un effetto particolare ma ogni carta  è equilibrata con le altre, quindi non esiste una carta più forte ed una più debole, è tutto in base a come il giocatore sceglie di giocare. Ogni giocatore può scegliere una carta tra tutte le carte speciali e inserirla nel mazzo!

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Bi Felicia and I am a skater with the Chicago Outfit. I'm starting my fifth season skating. I've also been a roller derby referee, announcer, coach, administrator... I wear a lot of helmets.

I'm coming to you with my project Derbs Against Originality, which is just Cards Against Humanity except about roller derby. It's a full game with over 500 cards! You can play it solo, you can mix it in with the Cards Against Humanity you already have. Both versions will be fun!

Risks & Challenges

I'm posting this today because I've been working on this for a few months and someone else came out with the same idea today and I think there's room for both of us. My campaign wasn't 100% ready for its rollout. But I can tell you where I'm at!

  • I have composed 400 cards as of January 13, 2016.
  • I have secured a retail partner to ship worldwide.
  • I have a print shop lined up and a tentative design.
  • I have long-term ambitions.
When you invest in Derbs Against Originality, you're not just buying a box of cards. You're investing in a larger campaign. What I mean is...
  • Expansion packs! Need more ref jokes? Not enough stuff about men's derby? NSO humor not your speed? Beef it up!
  • Yearly updates! Derby is an evolving, changing creature. If we'd launched a year ago, we would have missed out on such classic jokes as "The Rose City Rollers, Presented by Coca-Cola." Your deck can always be fresh!
  • Partnerships! Do you want to sell Derbs Against Originality at your merch table? Do you want your own expansion to cater to your own fan base? We can do it!

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out! We're second to market, but more projects = more LOLs! Mix and match. It's cool. No one ever won a bout by themselves or something. Share!

Stretch Goals

If we make it to $5500, we're gonna get some fancy packaging. A svelte box to show off how cool you are.
$6500, and I'm releasing a Ref/NSO expansion alongside the original edition.
$7500, and I'll build out an online version. Maybe I'll even be able to do a mobile version. Play during conference calls and stuff!

story:
If there is one thing that we love about games, is that they are always entertaining and help us to relax and have a good time. We can’t get enough of trying and getting addicted to new games that feed our curiosity and help us to stay away from the pressures of the day-to-day life for a while.

I know how it is and that’s why, as a gaming enthusiast and indie game designer, I decided to entirely create a new high quality virtual card and board game that I could share with the world.

Enter PAPER KINGDOM, an improvised game-play four player luck-based card cum board game that is based on a very popular game in India, my home country.

I have made PAPER KINGDOM with enhanced crisp and fun graphics and a more modern twist, giving it also a smart international feel, keeping in sight the kind of gaming profile that card and board games enthusiasts have.

PAPER KINGDOM is the perfect program for a group of four friends to relax and have fun together, in an entertaining and somewhat addictive way – you’ll find out that your greatest challenge may actually be to stop playing the game!


Four players are required to play Paper Kingdom. There are four cards in the game.

At the beginning of the round shuffle the cards and have every player take a card. They can look at it but can’t show it to anyone else. Whoever drew the king card turns it face up and gets 3 points.

Next whoever drew the guard card turns it face up. They have to guess which of the remaining two players has the thief card.

If they chose correctly they get two points, the thief gets 0 point and the player with the birdy card gets 1 point. If the guard chooses incorrectly, they get 0 point and the thief gets 2 points. Birdy still gets 1 point.

The king can choose to move forward 3 squares or to move forward 2 squares and then move an opposing player back 1 square. After all the cards are revealed, king moves after everyone does.

Birdy moves forward 1 square. Which ever player received 2 points moves 2 squares and which ever player received 0 point stays where they are.                                                                          

                                                                         The Board



While moving forward on the board, (a) If a player lands on a square which has minus one(-1) on it, he/she has to move one step back. (b) If someone lands on a square with plus one(+1), they can move one step forward. (c) If someone is having a bad day and lands on "Go to start", they go back to the start line.


If you enjoy gaming, and if you are especially into card and board games, you can get exciting special features while also becoming a pioneer funder of Paper Kingdom:

I invite you to choose one of the great rewards that I have on offer, with special edition cards and limited editions of the game for you, as an early backer.






 I also invite you to share this campaign with your friends and family who also enjoy gaming and who might want to secure their limited edition of Paper Kingdom.


If I manage to raise more than what I pledged, I'll create two more versions of the game and art books where I'll put all the art works together and everyone who helped this campaign by ordering any version of the game will get these extras for free.




My name is Apurba Debnath. I am an indie game designer, artist and animator.   I have been working in casual gaming industry for last 4 and half years and I've worked on many games for web and mobile platforms. I am the author of flash games "Die For a Lie" and "Humble Jungle Puzzle". "Die For a Lie" is a web based action-shooter game which was published by Armor Games. "Humble Jungle Puzzle" is a fun and kid friendly puzzle game and was published by Gamezhero. I am also developing casual games along with my mate, under the name Talltoy Games, 

at the same time my  focus is on  making some simple, quick and addictive card games and Paper Kingdom is my first card game that I am working on and since I have developed the advanced concept, with all the details, and will be taking its full development and production forward on my own, I am now raising funds to be able to finish the project, having a chance to fully focusing on making it absolutely engaging, both in terms of graphics, functions and fun-wise.

Thanks to Chintan, Shahad and Rajesh for helping me with testing the game. It was really a great time and thanks to Steven for his voice.  And my special thanks to Kevin MacLeod for his beautiful music track, that I used in the video.

story_txt:
If there is one thing
that we love about games, is that they are always entertaining and help us to
relax and have a good time. We can’t get enough of trying and getting addicted to new games that feed our curiosity and help us to stay away from the pressures
of the day-to-day life for a while.
I know how it is and
that’s why, as a gaming enthusiast and indie game designer, I decided to
entirely create a new high quality virtual card and board game that I could
share with the world. 
Enter PAPER KINGDOM, an
improvised game-play four player luck-based card cum board game that is based on a very
popular game in India, my home country.
I have made PAPER KINGDOM
with enhanced crisp and fun graphics and a more modern twist, giving it also a
smart international feel, keeping in sight the kind of gaming profile that card
and board games enthusiasts have.
PAPER KINGDOM is the
perfect program for a group of four friends to relax and have fun together, in
an entertaining and somewhat addictive way – you’ll find out that your greatest
challenge may actually be to stop playing the game!Four players are required to play Paper Kingdom. There are four cards in the game.At the beginning of the round shuffle the cards
and have every player take a card. They can look at it but can’t show it to
anyone else. Whoever drew the king card turns it face up and gets 3 points.

Next whoever drew the guard card turns it face
up. They have to guess which of the remaining two players has the thief card.
If they chose correctly they get two points, the
thief gets 0 point and the player with the birdy card gets 1 point. If the guard
chooses incorrectly, they get 0 point and the thief gets 2 points. Birdy
still gets 1 point.


The king can choose to move forward 3 squares or to move forward 2 squares and then move an opposing player back 1 square. After all the cards are revealed, king moves after everyone does.
Birdy moves forward 1 square. Which
ever player received 2 points moves 2 squares and which ever player received 0
point stays where they are.                                                                          
                                                                         The Board






While moving forward on the board, (a) If a player lands on a square which has minus one(-1) on it, he/she has to move one step back. (b) If someone lands on a square with plus one(+1), they can move one step forward. (c) If someone is having a bad day and lands on "Go to start", they go back to the start line.


If you enjoy gaming, and
if you are especially into card and board games, you can get exciting special
features while also becoming a pioneer funder of Paper Kingdom:

one of the great rewards that I have on offer, with special edition cards and limited
editions of the game for you, as an early backer. 







 I also invite you to share this campaign with your friends and family who also enjoy gaming and who might want to secure their limited edition of Paper Kingdom.





If I manage to raise more than what I pledged, I'll create two more versions of the game and art books where I'll put all the art works together and everyone who helped this campaign by ordering any version of the game will get these extras for free.
